definition: to dig into/to cut a mine into

to open/to start/to turn on/to boil/to write out (a prescription, check, invoice etc)/to operate (a vehicle)/carat (gold)/abbr. for Kelvin, 開爾文|开尔文[Kai1 er3 wen2]/abbr. for 開本|开本[kai1 ben3], book format

sentences.english: Why were we jumping into dug-up graves in Northern China?
sentences.chinese: 为什么我们说到了中国北方被挖开的墓？

sentences.english: Dig up the ground on that very spot and you will find your inheritance.
sentences.chinese: 挖开他站的那个地方，你就会找到那笔遗产。

sentences.english: The workmen exposed the gas pipe .
sentences.chinese: 工人们挖开地面使煤气管露出。

sentences.english: Bellick dug the hole in the guard room.
sentences.chinese: 贝里克挖开了警卫室的那个地洞。

sentences.english: When they dug away at the stones, they fell away revealing a skeleton behind them.
sentences.chinese: 挖开石头时，他们闪在一旁，露出他们身后的骷髅。

sentences.english: We counted eight dug-up graves in total, seemingly recent.
sentences.chinese: 我们总共数到8个看起来像是最近被挖开的墓。

definition: to pry open or apart/to spread (sth) open with both hands
to flatten/to level/to raze to the ground
